newsitem.title: USA: Johnson & Johnson manager awarded $11.7 million.
newsitem.headline: Johnson & Johnson manager awarded $11.7 million.

text.p: A federal court jury has awarded $11.7 million in damages to a sales manager at American pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson after finding the company retaliated against her for complaining of discrimination, her attorneys said on Friday.
A jury of six men and two women awarded the damages to Jennifer Passantino after a three-week trial in Tacoma, Washington, a Seattle law firm representing Passantino said.
The verdict was returned on June 19, but has only now been publicised by the law firm.
Passantino, 43, who lives in Lakewood, Washington, has worked for Johnson & Johnson Consumer Products Inc. since 1979, the last seven years as a national account manager.
The damages were for past and future economic losses of $2.1 million, emotional distress of $1 million and $8.6 million in punitive damages.

Federal law, however, places a ceiling on punitive damages of $300,000. U.S. District Judge Robert Bryan has yet to rule on whether the cap on punitive damages applies to this case, Passantino's attorney Victoria Vreeland said.
Johnson & Johnson, one of the world's leading drug manufacturers, said it was "an absolutely preposterous judgment, with no basis in fact, and we are confident it will be overturned on appeal."
Passantino's lawsuit against the company alleged gender discrimination and retaliation.

Her attorneys alleged she was passed over for promotions, despite high performance evaluations. Passantino took her grievance to the company's human resources department and later filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
After this, Passantino was offered lower level jobs, criticised in memos and classified internally as not qualified for upper management, Passantino's attorneys said.
The jury did not find that Passantino had been discriminated against but did find there was retaliation, according to Johnson & Johnson.
"We are grateful the jury found no discrimination in this case but vigorously disagree with their finding of retaliation," the company said in a statement.
